messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: For the last ten years, supermarkets did many bad things. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay their suppliers enough. They used too much plastic for packaging. This plastic hurt our environment. But now, supermarkets are listening. They are paying attention. Shoppers are very angry about the plastic packaging. So, some big UK supermarkets made a promise. They will change their packaging. They will use less plastic.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7057 is below the required 0.75. While the factual points are present, the core message's nuance regarding public scrutiny and the formal nature of the supermarkets' response has been diminished. The original text emphasizes 'come under fire with accusations' and 'consumer backlash' leading to signing 'a pact', which conveys a stronger sense of public pressure and a structured, formal response. Your version simplifies this to 'did many bad things' and 'shoppers are very angry' leading to 'made a promise', which loses some of the original's specific meaning and tone. Suggestion: Rephrase to better capture the idea of public accusations and formal agreements, even with simple A2 vocabulary. For example, 'People said supermarkets did bad things' or 'Supermarkets promised in a special way'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: For the last ten years, people said supermarkets did many bad things. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay their suppliers enough. They used too much plastic for packaging. This plastic hurt our environment. But now, supermarkets are listening. They are paying attention. Shoppers were very angry about the plastic packaging. They complained a lot. So, some big UK supermarkets signed a special paper. They made a promise. They will change their packaging. They will use less plastic.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7009 is below the required 0.75. The core message and nuance of the original text have been significantly diluted. The simplification has removed important aspects of the original meaning. Specific deviations are listed below. Deviation: The phrase 'come under fire with accusations of various unethical acts' was simplified to 'people said supermarkets did many bad things'. This loses the specific meaning of public scrutiny and moral failing implied by 'unethical acts' and 'come under fire'. 'Bad things' is too general. Deviation: The phrase 'growing consumer backlash against the huge amounts of plastic waste generated by plastic packaging' was simplified to 'Shoppers were very angry about the plastic packaging. They complained a lot.' This loses the stronger, more organized, and sustained negative reaction implied by 'backlash' and the specific detail of 'huge amounts of plastic waste generated'. Deviation: The phrase 'signed up to a pact promising to transform packaging and cut plastic wastage' was simplified to 'signed a special paper. They made a promise. They will change their packaging. They will use less plastic.' While this is a good simplification for A2, 'pact' implies a more formal agreement than 'special paper', and 'transform' suggests a more significant change than simply 'change'. Suggestion: Rephrase to more accurately convey the severity of the accusations and the nature of the consumer reaction, ensuring the core meaning of public criticism and formal agreement is retained within A2 vocabulary.

So, some big UK supermarkets signed an agreement. They made a promise. They will change their packaging a lot. They will use less plastic.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: For ten years, many big supermarkets got complaints. People accused them of bad acts. They wasted many tonnes of food. They underpaid their suppliers. They made too much plastic waste for packaging. This plastic hurt our environment. But now, supermarkets and grocers are starting to notice. Many shoppers were very angry. This was a big backlash. They did not like plastic packaging. So, some big UK supermarkets made a pact. They will transform packaging. They will cut plastic waste.
Feedback received: Grade 1/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The classifier rated the text as B1, not the required A2. This is a critical failure. The primary reason for this deviation is the consistent use of vocabulary above the A2 level. Specific deviations are as follows: The word 'accused' is classified as C1. An A2 text must use simpler phrasing such as 'people said they did bad things' or 'people complained about bad acts'. The word 'backlash' is above A2 level. While you attempted to explain it, the word itself is not A2. This concept must be conveyed using only A2 vocabulary, for example, 'Many shoppers were very angry about the plastic. They showed their anger'. The word 'transform' is classified as B1. An A2 text must use simpler words like 'change' or 'make new'. The word 'pact' is above A2 level. An A2 text must use simpler words like 'agreement' or 'promise'. The word 'waste' is classified as B1. This word is used multiple times and must be simplified or replaced with A2 terms like 'rubbish' or 'things thrown away' or by using phrases like 'too much plastic'.
